content:
Anna, I have no idea what is causing your issue(s) in Thunderbird, but you don't HAVE to use it to read and respond to your emails. What email provider are you using? Is it a gmail account, or Yahoo, or what? You can tell who your provider is by looking at your email address. For example, if it's a gmail account, it will be [your user ID]@gmail.com. Once you know who the provider is, you can access your email by logging into their server directly with your user id and password. Once you're logged in, your email will be available, links should work, and you won't get nagged for donations, and life will improve for you immeasurably. Then you can uninstall Thunderbird and be a happy camper once again!

If you don't know how to log in to the provider directly, please reply with who the provider is and someone (maybe me?) can coach you how to do so. Don't respond with your whole email address...just the provider.

Good luck!
creator: mike_the_wino

content:
The nature of a POP3 account is that it retrieves the emails from the Email Server and deletes their existence from there. So, yes, you could delete both but you would probably lose all your emails.

There are several possible ways around this but you should definitely back up all your profiles before trying anything.
creator: frisée

content:
It makes no sense to me that creating the IMAP account would have caused any mail duplication at the server. Did you also copy mail from the POP account to the IMAP account in Thunderbird maybe?

What is that weird "POP" folder you have under the Inbox of the POP account and the Trash of the IMAP? You must have created that folder yourself if it appears in the POP account…

Anyway, deleting the IMAP account should be no problem, but deleting the POP account, if you choose to delete both info and data, would cause you to lose all the mail downloaded by that account that's no longer on the server…
creator: DavidGG

The primary (formerly master) password only protects access to the saved passwords. It does not protect access to the program or the mail folders.

creator: sfhowes

content:
If you have the same account on your cell phone then the account you had on your computer was probably IMAP. It would be that that you would need to specify. Your password is something that is used on your Email Provider's server and is nothing to do with TB. If you can't remember it and need it, you need to contact your Email provider. If you didn't reinstall Thunderbird then the retrieval of passwords can be done by accessing the Hamburger icon (top right)/Settings/Search for 'Password'/Saved Passwords/Show Passwords (use your windows log in to access the information).

.oOo.

Wenn Sie dasselbe Konto auf Ihrem Mobiltelefon haben, war das Konto auf Ihrem Computer wahrscheinlich IMAP. Das müssten Sie angeben. Ihr Passwort wird auf dem Server Ihres E-Mail-Anbieters verwendet und hat nichts mit TB zu tun. Wenn Sie es vergessen haben und es brauchen, müssen Sie sich an Ihren E-Mail-Anbieter wenden. Wenn Sie Thunderbird nicht neu installiert haben, können Sie die Passwörter abrufen, indem Sie auf das Hamburger-Symbol (oben rechts)/Einstellungen/Nach „Passwort“ suchen/Gespeicherte Passwörter/Passwörter anzeigen zugreifen (verwenden Sie Ihre Windows-Anmeldung, um auf die Informationen zuzugreifen).

content:
That alert is a sign that you're trying to configure the account with wrong settings, more specifically you're telling Thunderbird to use as mail server something that isn't a mail server, which causes Thunderbird to not be able to find a certificate it expects the mail server to have.

I couldn't find configuration settings for that mail service provider. Looks like you have to install a "mail bridge" application in order to be able to use it with a mail client like Thunderbird. This is new to me, first time I hear of a mail service provider requiring a "mail bridge" in order for mail clients to be able to use it, so I cannot help you with that, other than referring you to the web page with the instructions:

https://proton.me/support/imap-smtp-and-pop3-setup
creator: DavidGG

content:
That page says this, though:

Proton Mail Bridge is currently available only if you have a paid Proton Mail plan.

So there must be a way to set up the mail client without the Mail Bridge, at least for free mail plans…
creator: DavidGG

content:
OK, sorry for the confusion, looks like you should be able to (manually) configure Thunderbird using the settings shown here:

https://www.getmailbird.com/setup/access-protonmail-com-via-imap-smtp
creator: DavidGG

content:
BLUTH said
Hello and thank you for your help On my PC my free account still works and I can send emails to my neuf account via the directory but the reverse no longer works my free address or others in the directory are no longer recognized when sending an email via neuf. On my smartphone I have bluemail for android and it continues to work normally with both my neuf and free mail accounts and I can send mail via neuf to my free address or others in the directory. On the PC I've tried deleting the neuf IMAP and SMPT account settings and copying the settings indicated in the smartphone, but alas this doesn't change anything. Do you think you can guess a possible way out While waiting for help I thank you cordially PS below the software's return message Sending the message failed An error occurred when sending the e-mail. the mail server replied: <carlos.pluvinage@free.fr>: Relay access denied. Please check the recipient address carlos.pluvinage@free.fr and try again.

I think the error is due to trying to send from the free account over the neuf smtp server. You must have separate smtp servers for each account, and set each account to send on the correct smtp - the one that has a matching User Name: the free account sends on the free smtp and the neuf account sends on the neuf smtp.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593
creator: sfhowes

content:
Typically, you only want to check Inbox for new messages, because that's where new messages arrive, so you reduce server load by telling the mail client to only look for new messages there.

If you were filtering messages at the server, though, before the mail client gets to see them, you'd want the mail client to also check the folders where those messages might have been moved, in order to be able to see whether new messages arrived there, and that's when you'd want to choose that option for those folders.

Well, there is always the possibility that this "friend" has access to the mail of either of you (e.g. because she somehow knows the account username and password needed to access it), but again that would be outside the scope of Thunderbird.

At any rate, if Thunderbird sent the message to the "friend" it can only have been because you put her address in the "From:", "Cc:" or "Bcc:" when sending the message, and you would be able to check that by looking at the copy of the sent message saved in your Sent folder.

content:
Account Actions below the list of accounts on the left of the Account Settings tab. Make sure you choose the right account first and don't delete the wrong account by mistake. You'll be given the option to delete both account info (i.e. settings) and message data. Choose both if that's what you want.

Your mail would be locally stored within your profile folder, but you don't have to touch anything there if you choose the option to delete message data when deleting the account:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data
creator: DavidGG
